children.value: Let’s look at some special matrices and determinants that are useful in economic analysis.

The Jacobian (named after German mathematician Karl Gustav Jacobi, 1804–1851) is generally used in conjunction with partial derivatives to provide an easy test for the existence of functional dependence (linear and nonlinear). A Jacobian determinant

children.html: ∣J∣|\mathbf{J}|∣J∣

children.value: is composed of all the first‑order partial derivatives of a system of equations, arranged in order sequence. Given

children.html: y1=f1(x1,x2,x3)y2=f2(x1,x2,x3)y3=f3(x1,x2,x3)y_{1} = f_{1}(x_{1},x_{2},x_{3}) \\ y_{2} = f_{2}(x_{1},x_{2},x_{3}) \\ y_{3} = f_{3}(x_{1},x_{2},x_{3})y1​=f1​(x1​,x2​,x3​)y2​=f2​(x1​,x2​,x3​)y3​=f3​(x1​,x2​,x3​)

∣J∣=∣∂y1∂x1∂y1∂x2∂y1∂x3∂y2∂x1∂y2∂x2∂y2∂x3∂y3∂x1∂y3∂x2∂y3∂x3∣|\mathbf{J}| = \begin{vmatrix} \frac{\partial y_{1}}{\partial x_{1}} & \frac{\partial y_{1}}{\partial x_{2}} & \frac{\partial y_{1}}{\partial x_{3}} \\[4pt] \frac{\partial y_{2}}{\partial x_{1}} & \frac{\partial y_{2}}{\partial x_{2}} & \frac{\partial y_{2}}{\partial x_{3}} \\[4pt] \frac{\partial y_{3}}{\partial x_{1}} & \frac{\partial y_{3}}{\partial x_{2}} & \frac{\partial y_{3}}{\partial x_{3}} \end{vmatrix}∣J∣=∣∣​∂x1​∂y1​​∂x1​∂y2​​∂x1​∂y3​​​∂x2​∂y1​​∂x2​∂y2​​∂x2​∂y3​​​∂x3​∂y1​​∂x3​∂y2​​∂x3​∂y3​​​∣∣​
y1=5x1+3x2y2=25x12+30x1x2+9x22y_{1} = 5x_{1} + 3x_{2} \\ y_{2} = 25x_{1}^{2} + 30x_{1}x_{2} + 9x_{2}^{2}y1​=5x1​+3x2​y2​=25x12​+30x1​x2​+9x22​

children.value: Then taking the first‑order partials gives

\frac{\partial y_1}{\partial x_1} = 5,\qquad 
\frac{\partial y_1}{\partial x_2} = 3,\qquad 
\frac{\partial y_2}{\partial x_1} = 50x_1 + 30x_2,\qquad 
\frac{\partial y_2}{\partial x_2} = 30x_1 + 18x_2
children.html: ∂y1∂x1=5,∂y1∂x2=3,∂y2∂x1=50x1+30x2,∂y2∂x2=30x1+18x2\frac{\partial y_1}{\partial x_1} = 5,\qquad \frac{\partial y_1}{\partial x_2} = 3,\qquad \frac{\partial y_2}{\partial x_1} = 50x_1 + 30x_2,\qquad \frac{\partial y_2}{\partial x_2} = 30x_1 + 18x_2∂x1​∂y1​​=5,∂x2​∂y1​​=3,∂x1​∂y2​​=50x1​+30x2​,∂x2​∂y2​​=30x1​+18x2​
∣J∣=∣5350x1+30x230x1+18x2∣|\mathbf{J}| = \begin{vmatrix} 5 & 3 \\ 50x_1 + 30x_2 & 30x_1 + 18x_2 \end{vmatrix}∣J∣=∣∣​550x1​+30x2​​330x1​+18x2​​∣∣​

children.value: The determinant of the Jacobian matrix is

children.html: ∣J∣=5(30x1+18x2)−3(50x1+30x2)=0|\mathbf{J}| = 5(30x_1 + 18x_2) - 3(50x_1 + 30x_2) = 0∣J∣=5(30x1​+18x2​)−3(50x1​+30x2​)=0
∣J∣=0|\mathbf{J}| = 0∣J∣=0

children.value: , there is functional dependence between the equations. (Note:

children.html: (5x1+3x2)2=25x12+30x1x2+9x22(5x_{1} + 3x_{2})^{2} = 25x_{1}^{2} + 30x_{1}x_{2} + 9x_{2}^{2}(5x1​+3x2​)2=25x12​+30x1​x2​+9x22​
zx=zy=0z_{x} = z_{y} = 0zx​=zy​=0

children.value: are met, a sufficient condition for a multivariate function

children.html: z=f(x,y)z = f(x,y)z=f(x,y)
zxx,zyy>0z_{xx}, z_{yy} > 0zxx​,zyy​>0
zxx,zyy<0z_{xx}, z_{yy} < 0zxx​,zyy​<0
zxxzyy>(zxy)2z_{xx} z_{yy} > (z_{xy})^{2}zxx​zyy​>(zxy​)2

children.value: A convenient test for this second‑order condition is provided by the Hessian. A Hessian

children.html: ∣H∣|\mathbf{H}|∣H∣

children.value: is a determinant composed of all the second‑order partial derivatives, with the second‑order direct partials on the principal diagonal and the second‑order cross partials off the principal diagonal. That is,

children.html: ∣H∣=∣zxxzxyzyxzyy∣|\mathbf{H}| = \begin{vmatrix} z_{xx} & z_{xy} \\ z_{yx} & z_{yy} \end{vmatrix}∣H∣=∣∣​zxx​zyx​​zxy​zyy​​∣∣​
zxy=zyxz_{xy} = z_{yx}zxy​=zyx​

children.value: If the first element on the principal diagonal, a.k.a. the first principal minor,

children.html: ∣H1∣=zxx|H_{1}| = z_{xx}∣H1​∣=zxx​

children.value: is positive, and the second principal minor

children.html: ∣H2∣=∣zxxzxyzyxzyy∣=zxxzyy−(zxy)2>0,|H_{2}| = \begin{vmatrix} z_{xx} & z_{xy} \\ z_{yx} & z_{yy} \end{vmatrix} = z_{xx} z_{yy} - (z_{xy})^{2} > 0,∣H2​∣=∣∣​zxx​zyx​​zxy​zyy​​∣∣​=zxx​zyy​−(zxy​)2>0,

children.value: then the second‑order conditions for a minimum are set. That is, when

children.html: ∣H1∣>0|H_{1}| > 0∣H1​∣>0
∣H2∣>0|H_{2}| > 0∣H2​∣>0
∣H∣|\mathbf{H}|∣H∣

children.value: . And a positive definite Hessian fulfills the second‑order conditions for a minimum.

children.html: ∣H1∣<0|H_{1}| < 0∣H1​∣<0

children.value: , while the second principal minor remains positive, then the second‑order conditions for a maximum are met. That is, when

children.html: ∣H1∣<0|H_{1}| < 0∣H1​∣<0
∣H2∣>0|H_{2}| > 0∣H2​∣>0
∣H∣|\mathbf{H}|∣H∣

children.value: and fulfills the second‑order conditions for a maximum.

∣H∣=∣4−1−14∣|\mathbf{H}| = \begin{vmatrix} 4 & -1 \\ -1 & 4 \end{vmatrix}∣H∣=∣∣​4−1​−14​∣∣​
∣H1∣=4>0|H_{1}| = 4 > 0∣H1​∣=4>0
∣H2∣=(4)(4)−(−1)2=16−1=15>0|H_{2}| = (4)(4) - (-1)^2 = 16 - 1 = 15 > 0∣H2​∣=(4)(4)−(−1)2=16−1=15>0
∣H1∣>0|H_{1}| > 0∣H1​∣>0
∣H2∣>0|H_{2}| > 0∣H2​∣>0

children.html: zzz

children.value: is characterized by a minimum at the critical values (can you find these?).
Determinants can be used to test for positive and negative definiteness of any quadratic form. The determinant of a quadratic form is called a

children.html: ∣D∣|\mathbf{D}|∣D∣

children.value: z = a x^{2} + b x y + c y^{2},
children.html: z=ax2+bxy+cy2,z = a x^{2} + b x y + c y^{2},z=ax2+bxy+cy2,

children.value: the determinant is formed by placing the coefficients of the squared terms on the principal diagonal and dividing the coefficients of the non‑squared terms equally between the off‑diagonal positions. Hence, we have

children.html: ∣D∣=∣ab/2b/2c∣|\mathbf{D}| = \begin{vmatrix} a & b/2 \\ b/2 & c \end{vmatrix}∣D∣=∣∣​ab/2​b/2c​∣∣​

children.value: We then evaluate the principal minors like we did for the Hessian test, where

children.html: ∣D1∣=aand∣D2∣=∣ab/2b/2c∣=ac−b24.|D_{1}| = a \quad \text{and} \quad |D_{2}| = \begin{vmatrix} a & b/2 \\ b/2 & c \end{vmatrix} = a c - \frac{b^{2}}{4}.∣D1​∣=aand∣D2​∣=∣∣​ab/2​b/2c​∣∣​=ac−4b2​.
∣D1∣,∣D2∣>0|D_{1}|, |D_{2}| > 0∣D1​∣,∣D2​∣>0
∣D∣|\mathbf{D}|∣D∣
zzz

children.value: is positive for all nonzero values of

children.html: xxx
yyy
∣D1∣<0|D_{1}| < 0∣D1​∣<0
∣D2∣>0|D_{2}| > 0∣D2​∣>0
∣D∣|\mathbf{D}|∣D∣
zzz

children.value: is negative for all nonzero values of

children.html: xxx
yyy
∣D2∣≠0|D_{2}| \neq 0∣D2​∣=0
zzz
zzz

children.value: may assume both positive and negative values.
Let’s take an example to test for sign definiteness of the following quadratic form

children.html: z=2x2+5xy+8y2.z = 2x^{2} + 5xy + 8y^{2}.z=2x2+5xy+8y2.

children.value: We can easily form the discriminant

children.html: ∣D∣=∣22.52.58∣|\mathbf{D}| = \begin{vmatrix} 2 & 2.5 \\ 2.5 & 8 \end{vmatrix}∣D∣=∣∣​22.5​2.58​∣∣​

children.value: Then evaluating the principal minors gives

children.html: ∣D1∣=2>0,∣D2∣=∣22.52.58∣=16−6.25=9.75>0.|D_{1}| = 2 > 0, \qquad |D_{2}| = \begin{vmatrix} 2 & 2.5 \\ 2.5 & 8 \end{vmatrix} = 16 - 6.25 = 9.75 > 0.∣D1​∣=2>0,∣D2​∣=∣∣​22.5​2.58​∣∣​=16−6.25=9.75>0.
zzz

children.value: is positive definite, meaning that it will be greater than zero for all nonzero values of

children.html: xxx
yyy

children.value: A quadratic form is defined as a polynomial expression in which each component term has a uniform degree.

6x^{2} - 2xy + 3y^{2} \quad \text{is a quadratic form in 2 variables.} \\
x^{2} + 2xy + 4xz + 2yz + y^{2} + z^{2} \quad \text{is a quadratic form in 3 variables.}
children.html: 6x2−2xy+3y2is a quadratic form in 2 variables.x2+2xy+4xz+2yz+y2+z2is a quadratic form in 3 variables.6x^{2} - 2xy + 3y^{2} \quad \text{is a quadratic form in 2 variables.} \\ x^{2} + 2xy + 4xz + 2yz + y^{2} + z^{2} \quad \text{is a quadratic form in 3 variables.}6x2−2xy+3y2is a quadratic form in 2 variables.x2+2xy+4xz+2yz+y2+z2is a quadratic form in 3 variables.

children.value: It would be useful to determine the sign definiteness so we can make statements concerning the optimum value of the function as to whether it is a minimum or a maximum.
More generally, a quadratic form in

A\mathbf{A}A
n×nn\times nn×n

x′Ax=[x1x2][1345][x1x2]=[x1+4x23x1+5x2][x1x2]=x12+7x1x2+5x22.\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix} x_{1} & x_{2} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_{1} \\ x_{2} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} x_{1} + 4x_{2} & 3x_{1} + 5x_{2} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_{1} \\ x_{2} \end{bmatrix} = x_{1}^{2} + 7x_{1}x_{2} + 5x_{2}^{2}.x′Ax=[x1​​x2​​][14​35​][x1​x2​​]=[x1​+4x2​​3x1​+5x2​​][x1​x2​​]=x12​+7x1​x2​+5x22​.

children.value: A quadratic form is said to be:

children.value: if it takes both positive and negative values.
Quadratic forms are particularly useful in determining the concavity or convexity of a differentiable function.

children.html: y=f(x1,x2,…,xn)y = f(x_{1},x_{2},\dots,x_{n})y=f(x1​,x2​,…,xn​)

children.value: , we can form the Hessian consisting of second‑order partial derivatives and construct a quadratic form as

children.html: x′Hx\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\mathbf{H}\mathbf{x}x′Hx
yyy

children.value: is strictly convex if the quadratic form is positive (implying that the Hessian is positive definite, i.e., the determinants of the principal minors are all positive).

children.html: yyy

children.value: is strictly concave if the quadratic form is negative (that is, the Hessian is negative definite, i.e. the determinants of the principal minors alternate in sign).
Let’s take an example to see this more clearly.

children.html: z=x2+y2.z = x^{2} + y^{2}.z=x2+y2.

children.value:
z_{x} = 2x,\quad z_{xx} = 2,\quad z_{xy} = 0, \\
z_{y} = 2y,\quad z_{yx} = 0,\quad z_{yy} = 2.
children.html: zx=2x,zxx=2,zxy=0,zy=2y,zyx=0,zyy=2.z_{x} = 2x,\quad z_{xx} = 2,\quad z_{xy} = 0, \\ z_{y} = 2y,\quad z_{yx} = 0,\quad z_{yy} = 2.zx​=2x,zxx​=2,zxy​=0,zy​=2y,zyx​=0,zyy​=2.
x′Hx=zxxx2+zyyy2+zxyzyxxy=2x2+2y2>0.\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\mathbf{H}\mathbf{x} = z_{xx}x^{2} + z_{yy}y^{2} + z_{xy}z_{yx}xy = 2x^{2} + 2y^{2} > 0.x′Hx=zxx​x2+zyy​y2+zxy​zyx​xy=2x2+2y2>0.
z=x2+y2z = x^{2} + y^{2}z=x2+y2

children.value: is characterized by a minimum at its optimal value and is therefore a strictly convex function. And it is easy to see that the Hessian is positive definite!
Say we have a quadratic form in 2 variables

children.html: z=8x2+6xy+2y2.z = 8x^{2} + 6xy + 2y^{2}.z=8x2+6xy+2y2.
z=8x2+3xy+3xy+2y2.z = 8x^{2} + 3xy + 3xy + 2y^{2}.z=8x2+3xy+3xy+2y2.

x′Hx=zxxx2+zyyy2+zxyzyxxy=8x2+2y2+(3)(3)xy=8x2+2y2+9xy.\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\mathbf{H}\mathbf{x} = z_{xx}x^{2} + z_{yy}y^{2} + z_{xy}z_{yx}xy = 8x^{2} + 2y^{2} + (3)(3)xy = 8x^{2} + 2y^{2} + 9xy.x′Hx=zxx​x2+zyy​y2+zxy​zyx​xy=8x2+2y2+(3)(3)xy=8x2+2y2+9xy.
H=[8332]\mathbf{H} = \begin{bmatrix} 8 & 3 \\ 3 & 2 \end{bmatrix}H=[83​32​]
∣H1∣=8|H_{1}| = 8∣H1​∣=8
∣8332∣\begin{vmatrix} 8 & 3 \\ 3 & 2 \end{vmatrix}∣∣​83​32​∣∣​

children.value: Both are positive so we have the Hessian and the quadratic form as positive definite.

children.html: y=f(x1,x2,x3)y = f(x_{1},x_{2},x_{3})y=f(x1​,x2​,x3​)

∣H∣=∣y11y12y13y21y22y23y31y32y33∣|\mathbf{H}| = \begin{vmatrix} y_{11} & y_{12} & y_{13} \\ y_{21} & y_{22} & y_{23} \\ y_{31} & y_{32} & y_{33} \end{vmatrix}∣H∣=∣∣​y11​y21​y31​​y12​y22​y32​​y13​y23​y33​​∣∣​

children.value: Conditions for a relative minimum or maximum depend on the signs of the first, second, and third principal minors, respectively. If

children.html: ∣H1∣>0,∣H2∣=∣y11y12y21y22∣>0,and∣H3∣=∣H∣>0,|H_{1}| > 0,\quad |H_{2}| = \begin{vmatrix} y_{11} & y_{12} \\ y_{21} & y_{22} \end{vmatrix} > 0,\quad \text{and} \quad |H_{3}| = |\mathbf{H}| > 0,∣H1​∣>0,∣H2​∣=∣∣​y11​y21​​y12​y22​​∣∣​>0,and∣H3​∣=∣H∣>0,
∣H∣|\mathbf{H}|∣H∣

children.value: is positive definite and fulfills the second‑order conditions for a minimum.

children.html: ∣H1∣<0,∣H2∣=∣y11y12y21y22∣>0,and∣H3∣=∣H∣<0,|H_{1}| < 0,\quad |H_{2}| = \begin{vmatrix} y_{11} & y_{12} \\ y_{21} & y_{22} \end{vmatrix} > 0,\quad \text{and} \quad |H_{3}| = |\mathbf{H}| < 0,∣H1​∣<0,∣H2​∣=∣∣​y11​y21​​y12​y22​​∣∣​>0,and∣H3​∣=∣H∣<0,
∣H∣|\mathbf{H}|∣H∣

children.value: is negative definite and fulfills the second‑order conditions for a maximum.

children.html: y=−5x12+10x1+x1x3−2x22+4x2+2x2x3−4x32.y = -5x_{1}^{2} + 10x_{1} + x_{1}x_{3} - 2x_{2}^{2} + 4x_{2} + 2x_{2}x_{3} - 4x_{3}^{2}.y=−5x12​+10x1​+x1​x3​−2x22​+4x2​+2x2​x3​−4x32​.

children.value:
\frac{\partial y}{\partial x_1} = y_1 = -10x_1 + 10 + x_3 = 0, \\
\frac{\partial y}{\partial x_2} = y_2 = -4x_2 + 2x_3 + 4 = 0, \\
\frac{\partial y}{\partial x_3} = y_3 = x_1 + 2x_2 - 8x_3 = 0.

children.value: Let’s take the second partial derivatives from the first‑order conditions to create the Hessian,

children.html: y11=−10,y12=0,y13=1,y21=0,y22=−4,y23=2,y31=1,y32=2,y33=−8.y_{11} = -10,\quad y_{12} = 0,\quad y_{13} = 1, \\ y_{21} = 0,\quad y_{22} = -4,\quad y_{23} = 2, \\ y_{31} = 1,\quad y_{32} = 2,\quad y_{33} = -8.y11​=−10,y12​=0,y13​=1,y21​=0,y22​=−4,y23​=2,y31​=1,y32​=2,y33​=−8.
H=[−10010−4212−8]\mathbf{H} = \begin{bmatrix} -10 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -4 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & -8 \end{bmatrix}H=⎣⎡​−1001​0−42​12−8​⎦⎤​

children.value: Finally, applying the Hessian test, we have

children.html: ∣H1∣=−10<0,∣H2∣=∣−1000−4∣=40>0,∣H3∣=∣H∣=∣−10010−4212−8∣=−80<0.|H_1| = -10 < 0,\quad |H_2| = \begin{vmatrix} -10 & 0 \\ 0 & -4 \end{vmatrix} = 40 > 0,\quad |H_3| = |\mathbf{H}| = \begin{vmatrix} -10 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -4 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & -8 \end{vmatrix} = -80 < 0.∣H1​∣=−10<0,∣H2​∣=∣∣​−100​0−4​∣∣​=40>0,∣H3​∣=∣H∣=∣∣​−1001​0−42​12−8​∣∣​=−80<0.

children.value: Since the principal minors alternate correctly in sign, the Hessian is negative definite and the function is maximized at

children.html: x1≈1.04x_1 \approx 1.04x1​≈1.04
x2≈1.22x_2 \approx 1.22x2​≈1.22
x3≈0.43x_3 \approx 0.43x3​≈0.43
f(x1,x2)f(x_1, x_2)f(x1​,x2​)
g(x1,x2)g(x_1, x_2)g(x1​,x2​)

children.value: the first‑order conditions can be found by setting up what is known as the Lagrangian function
F(x_1, x_2, \lambda) = f(x_1, x_2) - \lambda(g(x_1, x_2) - c)
children.html: F(x1,x2,λ)=f(x1,x2)−λ(g(x1,x2)−c)F(x_1, x_2, \lambda) = f(x_1, x_2) - \lambda(g(x_1, x_2) - c)F(x1​,x2​,λ)=f(x1​,x2​)−λ(g(x1​,x2​)−c)

children.value: The second‑order conditions can be expressed in terms of a bordered Hessian

children.html: ∣Hˉ∣|\bar{\mathbf{H}}|∣Hˉ∣
∣Hˉ∣=∣0g1g2g1F11F12g2F21F22∣|\bar{\mathbf{H}}| = \begin{vmatrix} 0 & g_1 & g_2 \\ g_1 & F_{11} & F_{12} \\ g_2 & F_{21} & F_{22} \end{vmatrix}∣Hˉ∣=∣∣​0g1​g2​​g1​F11​F21​​g2​F12​F22​​∣∣​
∣Hˉ∣=∣0g1g2g1f11f12g2f21f22∣|\bar{\mathbf{H}}| = \begin{vmatrix} 0 & g_1 & g_2 \\ g_1 & f_{11} & f_{12} \\ g_2 & f_{21} & f_{22} \end{vmatrix}∣Hˉ∣=∣∣​0g1​g2​​g1​f11​f21​​g2​f12​f22​​∣∣​

children.value: which is the usual Hessian bordered by the first derivatives of the constraint with zero on the principal diagonal.
The order of a bordered principal minor is determined by the order of the principal minor being bordered. Hence

children.html: ∣Hˉ2∣|\bar{H}_2|∣Hˉ2​∣

children.value: above represents a second bordered principal minor, because the principal minor being bordered has dimensions

children.html: 2×22\times 22×2

children.value: For the bivariate case with a single constraint, we simply look at

children.html: ∣Hˉ2∣|\bar{H}_2|∣Hˉ2​∣

children.value: . If this is negative, the bordered Hessian is said to be positive definite and satisfies the second‑order condition for a minimum. However, if it is positive, the bordered Hessian is said to be negative definite, and meets the sufficient conditions for a maximum.
Let’s try optimizing the following objective function

children.html: f(x1,x2)=4x12+3x22−2x1x2f(x_1, x_2) = 4x_1^2 + 3x_2^2 - 2x_1x_2f(x1​,x2​)=4x12​+3x22​−2x1​x2​
x1+x2=56.x_1 + x_2 = 56.x1​+x2​=56.

children.value: Setting up the Lagrangian function, taking the first‑order partials and solving gives

children.html: x1∗=36x_1^* = 36x1∗​=36
x2∗=20x_2^* = 20x2∗​=20
λ=348\lambda = 348λ=348

children.value: The bordered Hessian for this optimization problem is

children.html: ∣Hˉ∣=∣01118−21−26∣|\bar{\mathbf{H}}| = \begin{vmatrix} 0 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 8 & -2 \\ 1 & -2 & 6 \end{vmatrix}∣Hˉ∣=∣∣​011​18−2​1−26​∣∣​

children.value: Starting with the second principal minor, we have

children.html: ∣Hˉ2∣=∣Hˉ∣=0⋅∣8−2−26∣−1⋅∣1−216∣+1⋅∣181−2∣=−(6+2)+(−2−8)=−8−10=−18.|\bar{H}_2| = |\bar{\mathbf{H}}| = 0 \cdot \begin{vmatrix} 8 & -2 \\ -2 & 6 \end{vmatrix} - 1 \cdot \begin{vmatrix} 1 & -2 \\ 1 & 6 \end{vmatrix} + 1 \cdot \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 8 \\ 1 & -2 \end{vmatrix} = - (6+2) + (-2-8) = -8 -10 = -18.∣Hˉ2​∣=∣Hˉ∣=0⋅∣∣​8−2​−26​∣∣​−1⋅∣∣​11​−26​∣∣​+1⋅∣∣​11​8−2​∣∣​=−(6+2)+(−2−8)=−8−10=−18.
∣Hˉ∣|\bar{\mathbf{H}}|∣Hˉ∣

children.value: is positive definite and we have met sufficient conditions for a minimum.
For the more general case in which the objective function has say

children.html: nnn
f(x1,…,xn)f(x_1, \ldots , x_n)f(x1​,…,xn​)

children.value: which is subject to some constraint

children.html: g(x1,…,xn)g(x_1, \ldots , x_n)g(x1​,…,xn​)

children.value: , we can set up the bordered Hessian as

children.html: ∣Hˉ∣=[0g1g2…gng1F11F12…F1ng2F21F22…F2n⋮⋮⋮⋱⋮gnFn1Fn2…Fnn]|\bar{\mathbf{H}}| = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & g_1 & g_2 & \dots & g_n \\ g_1 & F_{11} & F_{12} & \dots & F_{1n} \\ g_2 & F_{21} & F_{22} & \dots & F_{2n} \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ g_n & F_{n1} & F_{n2} & \dots & F_{nn} \end{bmatrix}∣Hˉ∣=⎣⎡​0g1​g2​⋮gn​​g1​F11​F21​⋮Fn1​​g2​F12​F22​⋮Fn2​​………⋱…​gn​F1n​F2n​⋮Fnn​​⎦⎤​
∣Hˉ∣=∣Hˉn∣|\bar{\mathbf{H}}| = |\bar{H}_n|∣Hˉ∣=∣Hˉn​∣
n×nn \times nn×n

children.value: In this case, if all the principal minors are negative, i.e.

children.html: ∣Hˉ2∣,∣Hˉ3∣,…,∣Hˉn∣<0|\bar{H}_2|, |\bar{H}_3|, \ldots , |\bar{H}_n| < 0∣Hˉ2​∣,∣Hˉ3​∣,…,∣Hˉn​∣<0

children.value: , the bordered Hessian is said to be positive definite and satisfies the second‑order condition for a minimum.
On the other hand, if the principal minors alternate consistently in sign from positive to negative, i.e.

children.html: ∣Hˉ2∣>0,∣Hˉ3∣<0,∣Hˉ4∣>0|\bar{H}_2| > 0, |\bar{H}_3| < 0, |\bar{H}_4| > 0∣Hˉ2​∣>0,∣Hˉ3​∣<0,∣Hˉ4​∣>0

children.value: etc., the bordered Hessian is negative definite, and meets the sufficient conditions for a maximum.

children.value: is the final demand for product

children.html: iii

children.value: . What is important to realize here is that the total demand for a product consists of that product being the final demand plus that product being an intermediate good required for the production of other products.

children.html: X=[x1x2⋮xn],A=[a11a12…a1na21a22…a2n⋮⋮⋱⋮an1an2…ann],B=[b1b2⋮bn].\mathbf{X} = \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ \vdots \\ x_n \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{A} = \begin{bmatrix} a_{11} & a_{12} & \dots & a_{1n} \\ a_{21} & a_{22} & \dots & a_{2n} \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ a_{n1} & a_{n2} & \dots & a_{nn} \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{B} = \begin{bmatrix} b_1 \\ b_2 \\ \vdots \\ b_n \end{bmatrix}.X=⎣⎡​x1​x2​⋮xn​​⎦⎤​,A=⎣⎡​a11​a21​⋮an1​​a12​a22​⋮an2​​……⋱…​a1n​a2n​⋮ann​​⎦⎤​,B=⎣⎡​b1​b2​⋮bn​​⎦⎤​.

children.value: is called the matrix of technical coefficients.
To find the output (intermediate and final goods) needed to satisfy demand, all we have to do is to solve for

children.html: X\mathbf{X}X

X−AX=B⇒(I−A)X=B⇒X=(I−A)−1B.\mathbf{X} - \mathbf{A}\mathbf{X} = \mathbf{B} \quad \Rightarrow \quad (\mathbf{I} - \mathbf{A})\mathbf{X} = \mathbf{B} \quad \Rightarrow \quad \mathbf{X} = (\mathbf{I} - \mathbf{A})^{-1}\mathbf{B}.X−AX=B⇒(I−A)X=B⇒X=(I−A)−1B.

children.value: Let’s continue with the example above to find the characteristic vector.
We know one of the roots

children.html: λ=−9\lambda = -9λ=−9

children.html: (A−λI)v=0⇒[−6−(−9)33−6−(−9)][v1v2]=[3333][v1v2]=[00].(\mathbf{A} - \lambda \mathbf{I})\mathbf{v} = \mathbf{0} \quad \Rightarrow \quad \begin{bmatrix} -6 - (-9) & 3 \\ 3 & -6 - (-9) \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 3 \\ 3 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}.(A−λI)v=0⇒[−6−(−9)3​3−6−(−9)​][v1​v2​​]=[33​33​][v1​v2​​]=[00​].

children.value: Since the coefficient matrix is linearly dependent, there are infinite number of solutions. The product of the matrices gives two equations which are identical:

children.html: 3v1+3v2=0⇒v2=−v1.3v_1 + 3v_2 = 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad v_2 = -v_1.3v1​+3v2​=0⇒v2​=−v1​.
v12+v22=1.v_1^{2} + v_2^{2} = 1.v12​+v22​=1.
v2=−v1v_2 = -v_1v2​=−v1​
v12+(−v1)2=1⇒2v12=1⇒v12=12.v_1^{2} + (-v_1)^{2} = 1 \quad \Rightarrow \quad 2v_1^{2} = 1 \quad \Rightarrow \quad v_1^{2} = \frac{1}{2}.v12​+(−v1​)2=1⇒2v12​=1⇒v12​=21​.
